DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the bombings.
DOC.TEXT: ``He said they were very concerned about it; there are reasons to believe that at least part of the motivation was racial,'' Lowery said. ``We're very concerned, and I was pleased (that he called.)'' FBI agent William Hinshaw in Atlanta said the NAACP's southeast regional headquarters in Atlanta has been warned that the bombs appeared to be related to a Aug. 22 tear-gas mail bomb that exploded there, injuring eight people. In Montgomery, Ala., U.S. Marshal Jim Hudson said a federal judge received a telephone death threat early Tuesday. He would not identify the judge. Police in Birmingham rushed Tuesday to investigate a package mailed to Councilman David Herring, a longtime friend of Vance. It turned out to be a delivery from an Atlanta business. Meanwhile, a government source in Washington said the bomb that killed Vance bore the return address of Lewis F. Morgan, a senior 11th Circuit judge in Georgia. Morgan is not a suspect, the source said, but the discovery means the killer knew a great deal about Vance's personal habits and friendships. Links between Vance and Robinson are not readily apparent, other than their moderate-to-progressive politics. Vance, who was white, became known as a racially progressive Alabama Democratic leader before being elevated to the federal bench, while Robinson was known as a ``moderate, reasonable'' attorney and politician in Savannah. One of Robinson's biggest cases as a lawyer did go before the appeals court. He helped represent a black group fighting desegregation plans by the Savannah-Chatham County schools, which were approved by the 11th Circuit Court this fall. But Vance was not among the three 11th Circuit judges ruling on the case. ``It was a case that we lost _ it wasn't like Robinson could have been accused of doing anything to upset the community,'' said Lowell Johnston, the lead attorney from the NAACP Legal Defense Fund who worked the case with Robinson. Earlier this year, the Jacksonville NAACP won from the 11th Circuit a unanimous decision reinstating school busing in Jacksonville, overruling a lower court judge who had declared the school system was integrated. Vance wrote the opinion in that case. Vance, 58, ruled in at least one other major race-related case. The 11th Circuit in 1985 overturned a lower court's ruling and cleared the way for prosecution of 10 Ku Klux Klansmen for a bloody May 1979 confrontation with black civil rights marchers in Decatur, Ala. After the ruling, all 10 defendants pleaded guilty or were convicted. The 11th Circuit, based in Atlanta, handles federal appeals from Alabama, Georgia and Florida. Authorities said the Atlanta bomb was in a mailed package addressed to the 11th Circuit court, not to a particular individual.
